meta.title: Demonstrate understanding of trends in human evolution
meta.purpose: This achievement standard involves demonstrating understanding of trends in human evolution, including biological and cultural changes and patterns of hominin dispersal, using scientific evidence.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved-level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved-level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved-level indicators are met; no Merit-level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence-level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

key_terms.definition: Living and fossil species belonging to the human lineage, a subgroup of hominids.
Change over a period of time in relation to biological evolution, cultural evolution, and patterns of dispersal of hominins.
Regular, upright walking on two legs as the primary form of locomotion.

omis.description: Describes key biological trends such as bipedalism, skull changes, or hand manipulation.
omis.detection_hint: The response must identify and describe at least one trend in biological evolution. Listing without explanation is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The pelvis is shorter and broader in humans.
The spine is S-shaped to support upright walking.

omis.description: Describes key cultural trends such as tool use, fire, clothing, or shelter.
omis.detection_hint: Response must state a cultural development and describe its use or function. Naming only is not sufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Neanderthals used fibres to create cord for carrying food.
Fire was used for warmth and cooking.

omis.description: Defines hominins and describes their dispersal patterns.
omis.detection_hint: Response must clearly state the definition of hominins and mention migration/dispersal routes or patterns. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Hominins moved out of Africa into Europe and Asia.
Hominins are members of the human lineage, not including great apes.

omis.description: Explains how skeletal or anatomical features support bipedalism.
omis.detection_hint: Must connect feature to function or advantage (e.g., valgus angle improves walking efficiency). Description alone is not enough. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The valgus angle positions knees under the body for better balance.
The spine’s S-shape absorbs shock during walking.

omis.description: Explains the function of a specific brain region and its role in hominin behaviour.
omis.detection_hint: Student must name a brain region and link it to a function (e.g., language, tool use). Naming only is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The parietal lobe allowed spatial reasoning for tool making.
Broca’s area helped with speech development.

omis.description: Links anatomical or behavioural features to survival or evolutionary advantage.
omis.detection_hint: Must show how a feature (e.g., tool use, upright walking) contributed to reproductive or survival success. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Bipedalism freed hands for carrying tools and infants.
Tool use increased food access and survival.

omis.description: Evaluates trade-offs associated with an evolutionary change (e.g., costs and benefits).
omis.detection_hint: Student must describe both advantages and disadvantages of a feature and provide reasoning or outcomes. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Bipedalism increases injury risk but is efficient for travel.
Large brain size led to birth complications but improved cognition.

omis.description: Integrates biological and cultural trends to explain evolutionary outcomes.
omis.detection_hint: Must combine at least one biological and one cultural factor and explain their interaction or combined effect. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Smaller body size and simple tools helped H. floresiensis survive on limited island resources.

omis.description: Uses scientific evidence to justify or analyse evolutionary interpretations.
omis.detection_hint: Requires references to specific fossil, genetic, or archaeological evidence supporting the argument. General statements are not sufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The use of fibres shows cognitive ability supported by archaeological findings in France.

omis.description: Structures ideas logically and uses coherent links between concepts.
omis.detection_hint: Look for logical flow and connections between trends, ideas, or examples. A list of facts without linking phrases does not meet this indicator. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The advantages outweigh the disadvantages because they improved long-distance travel, which helped find food and escape predators.
